alert.note: Alert for Washington (Louisiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 09 at 8:13PM CST until February 11 at 11:00AM CST by NWS New Orleans
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Mississippi...Louisiana... Bogue Chitto River Near Tylertown affecting Walthall and Pike Counties. Bogue Chitto River Near Bush affecting St. Tammany Parish. East Hobolochitto Creek Near Caesar affecting Pearl River County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Louisiana...Mississippi... Bogue Chitto River At Franklinton affecting Washington Parish. West Hobolochitto Creek Near McNeil affecting Pearl River County. Pearl River Near Pearl River affecting Hancock, Pearl River and St. Tammany Counties. Pearl River Near Bogalusa affecting Pearl River and Washington Counties. For the Bogue Chitto River...including Tylertown, Franklinton, Bush...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lower Pearl River...including Bogalusa, Pearl River... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the West Hobolochitto Creek...including McNeil...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the East Hobolochitto Creek...including Caesar...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY AFTERNOON TO LATE SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Bogue Chitto River At Franklinton. * WHEN...From Friday afternoon to late Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, The national guard armory and parish corrections facility will require flood protection measures as river front property will flood. Sand bagging is recommended * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:15 PM CST Thursday the stage was 8.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early tomorrow afternoon to a crest of 12.5 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.4 feet on 12/31/2006. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/lix. Click on the Rivers and Lakes menu for forecasts and observations. The next statement will be issued when updates are needed.
